description: From Middle English grisely, grysly, grissliȝ, griselich, grislich, from Old English grisliċ (“grisly, horrible; dreadful, horrid”), from grīsan (“to shudder with horror; to tremble, to be terrified; to make tremble, to terrify; to agrise, grise”) (unattested but implied in āgrīsan) + -lic (suffix forming adjectives meaning ‘characteristic of, pertaining to’).
The word may also be an aphetic form of Old English ongrislic, agrisenliċ, the past participle of agrīsan (“to agrise”).
Compare Danish grusom, Swedish gräslig, Middle Dutch grezelijc (modern Dutch griezelig), Middle High German grisenlich (modern German grässlich, grausen).

examples: Synonyms: (obsolete) grisy, gristly, (misspellings) grizzly; see also Thesaurus:frightening
The photographs of the killings depict a grisly scene.
The animals found in this province are, deer, elk, buffalo, cabrie, the grisly black bear, and wild horses.

entries.meaning: Obsolete form of grizzly (“type of bear”).

description: From grisle (“horror, terror”) +‎ -ly; compare Middle Dutch griselike, Middle Low German grislike.

adverbs.description: grisly (comparative more grisly, superlative most grisly)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In a horrible or terrible manner; in a terrifying way.
